snippet: Even among people who don’t meet the criteria of obstructive sleep apnea, snorting and stopped breathing is linked to an increased risk of depression.
abstract: Anne G Wheaton study in journal Sleep finds that snorting and stopping breathing during sleep are associated with depression, even in people whose symptoms do not meet the criteria for a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea.
lead_paragraph: Even among people who don’t meet the criteria of obstructive sleep apnea, snorting and stopped breathing is linked to an increased risk of depression.

headline.seo: Less Severe Sleep Disorders Also Raise Depression Risk
headline.main: Hazards: Mild Sleep Disorders Tied to Depression
headline.print_headline: Hazards: Mild Sleep Disorders Tied to Depression
